titleStmt.title: Genomics and development of Nematostella vectensis and other anthozoans

affiliation.orgName: Sars International Centre for Marine Molecular Biology
Department of Molecular Evolution and Development

analytic.title: Genomics and development of Nematostella vectensis and other anthozoans

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Due to their rather simple body plan with only few organs and a low number of cell types, cnidarians have long been recognized as an important animal group for evolutionary comparisons of animal body plans. Recent studies have shown, however, that the genomes of cnidarians and their epigenetic and posttranscriptional regulation are more complex than their morphology might suggest. How these complex genomes are deployed during embryonic development is an open question. With a focus on the sea anemone Nematostella vectensis we describe new findings about the development of the nervous system from neural progenitor cells and how Wnt and BMP signalling control axial patterning. These studies show that beyond evolutionary comparisons, cnidarian model organisms can provide new insights into generic questions in developmental biology.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: As the sister group to bilaterians, cnidarians occupy a phylogenetically informative position for understanding the evolutionary origin of features of bilaterian genomes and developmental processes [1,2]. The development and the body plan of cnidarian polyps differ from bilaterians in some key aspects: they develop from only two germ layers, lack a morphologically centralized nervous system and they have (except for some species) only one externally visible body axis. Cnidarians can be subdivided into two major groups, the anthozoans and the medusozoans. While most cnidarians develop via a planula larva into sessile polyps, the large group of medusozoans possesses an additional life stage, the free-swimming medusa, which develops from the polyp by a budding process or by strobilation [3,4 ] (see article by Leclè re and Houliston, in this issue). Despite these clear developmental and morphological differences, cnidarians possess a repertoire of developmental genes that is remarkably similar to that of bilaterians [5,6]. This combination of genomic similarity and morphological dissimilarity can be exploited to understand how changes in the deployment of conserved developmental regulators may have contributed to the evolution of bilaterian body plans.

Here we describe recent advances in the understanding of the genome biology and the embryonic development of anthozoans with particular focus on Nematostella vectensis, a sea anemone, which is currently the most thoroughly studied anthozoan model system and for which a welldeveloped experimental toolkit is available.

div.head: The experimental toolkits and resources for anthozoan model systems
div.p: While genomic and transcriptomic resources are available for many anthozoans (e.g. [5,[7][8][9][10][11][12][13][14]15 ]), access to embryonic material can be a bottleneck for experimental work on their development. Nematostella can be maintained in the lab over its full life cycle, with a generation time of about four months and simple protocols for the induction of gametogenesis throughout the year [16,17]. This has facilitated the adoption of many molecular techniques, including in situ hybridization, gene knockdown, stable transgenesis and CRISPR/Cas9-mediated genome editing [18-20,21 ,22,23]. Aiptasia sp. is a sea anemone that is becoming a model for the cell biology and genetics of cnidarian-dinoflagellate symbiosis ( [24,25] and see the following section). In the wild, Aiptasia can spawn throughout the year [26] and recently, a protocol for the induction of spawning in the laboratory, based on simulation of the lunar cycle, has been introduced [27]. While the maintenance of Aiptasia throughout the full life cycle has not been reported yet, the facilitated access to embryos will likely lead to the expansion of the available molecular methodology that is required for in-depth analyses of developmental processes (e.g. [28]). In contrast to Nematostella and Aiptasia, Acropora coral species can be used as models for calcification (e.g. [29][30][31][32]), which is of general interest for our understanding of how coral reefs are built. Many Acropora species spawn only once or twice per year and there is currently no published protocol for the induction of gametogenesis. Despite this limitation, gene expression studies in Acropora millepora have been important for delimiting the degree of conservation of developmental programs within hexacorallian anthozoans (e.g. [33][34][35]).

div.head: Content and organization of anthozoan genomes
div.p: Nematostella was the first non-bilaterian animal whose genome was sequenced [5]. This revealed a surprisingly conserved genetic architecture, reflecting an unanticipated genome complexity ancestral for cnidarians and bilaterians. For instance, Nematostella has preserved 11 out of 12 known subfamilies of Wnt signalling molecules [36], many of which were lost in Drosophila and Caenorhabditis. It also possesses virtually all known bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) and Wnt antagonists, while the ecdysozoan model organisms have a very restricted set of these antagonists. During the last few years the genomes of several other cnidarian species have been sequenced and revealed striking patterns of conservation, but also significant lineage-specific gains as well as losses. Among the anthozoans, the genomes of the sea anemone Aiptasia pallida [15 ] and the reef-building coral Acropora digitifera [13 ] have been sequenced. Both contain (in contrast to Nematostella) the dinoflagellate Symbiodinium sp. as symbiotic algae and their genomes might offer insights into selection, uptake, maintenance and dependence of the symbiont [37]. For instance, the lack of an enzyme for cysteine synthesis, Cystathionine-b-synthase, in the coral, but not the sea anemone genome might reflect the less strict dependency of the sea anemone on the symbiont [13 ,15 ]. Host-symbiont interactions are crucial for symbiogenesis and may rely on components related to the innate immune system. Interestingly, both Aiptasia and some corals, but not Nematostella, have independently expanded the repertoire of cnidarian-specific Ficolin-like proteins (CnFL), which have similarity to pattern recognition receptors and may play a role in host-symbiont and/ or host-microbe interactions [15 ].

div.head: The regulation of the Nematostella genome and transcriptome
div.p: The stunning complexity of the gene repertoire of anthozoan genomes is in apparent contradiction to the relative simplicity of the body plan of corals and sea anemones. To address whether the cis-regulatory landscape of cnidarians is simpler or similar to that of bilaterians, several histone modifications characteristic of enhancers and promoters have been mapped by ChIPseq on the genome-wide level in Nematostella [38 ,39]. The results showed that the 'grammar' of histone codes is preserved in cnidarians and therefore must predate the origin of eumetazoans. Distinct subsets of enhancers are deployed at gastrula and planula stages, respectively, suggesting a developmental regulation of enhancer activity. Like in bilaterians, developmental genes tend to have more enhancers than house-keeping genes. Thus, the general logic of cis-regulation is conserved and predates the origin of Eumetazoa.

Besides cis-regulation, post-transcriptional regulation by miRNAs has been a major focus of research during the last decade [40]. In a pioneering study assessing the miRNA content in basal metazoans as well as choanoflagellates, 40 miRNAs were discovered in Nematostella [41]. Recently, this number was expanded to 87 by sequencing 8 developmental stages [42 ]. This is in line with the 126 miRNA loci detected in Hydra [43]. Surprisingly, cnidarian miRNAs predominantly bind to their targets not only with the seven nucleotide long seed region, but with almost perfect 22-24 nucleotide complementarity. This leads -through Argonaute protein -to slicing of the target mRNA at position 10/11 of the binding site of the miRNA [42 ]. This is fundamentally different than the predominant 'seed-matching' mechanism in bilaterians, but very similar to the mechanism of plant miRNAs, which are thought to have evolved independently [44]. Notably, all non-bilaterians (Ctenophora, Cnidaria, Porifera, Placozoa) possess a biogenesis factor, HYL-1 that was considered to be plant-specific [45]. Although it remains to be shown, whether plants and cnidarians really use the same miRNA biogenesis pathway, these observations raise the possibility that plant and animal miRNAs have a common origin, derived from a more ancient siRNA-like mechanism.

Significant advances have also been made recently on the proteomics of specific developmental stages and cell types of Nematostella and other cnidarians (e.g. [46][47][48][49][50][51]). Parallel studies of transcriptomes and proteomes under various physiological and developmental conditions are now feasible and will become more important in the future [52 ,53]. They will likely also foster more detailed investigations of the function and impact of miRNAs on the protein network.

div.head: Patterning of the body axes
div.p: In bilaterians, the patterning of the anterior-posterior (A-P) axis is a key determinant of the orderly formation of many body structures like organs and appendages and changes in A-P patterning can contribute to the evolution of body plans. Cnidarian polyps, in contrast, lack organs and display only few morphologically distinguishable features along their primary body axis (termed the oral-aboral axis). Anthozoans also have a secondary body axis (termed the directive axis and running orthogonal to the oral-aboral axis), which manifests in rather subtle asymmetries of the mesenteries and a longitudinal ciliated groove, the syphonoglyph and which can be visible by the shape of the oral opening. Whether the comparably low morphological complexity along the cnidarian body axes is due to different or less elaborate patterning systems has been a central question for cnidarian developmental biology over the last decades.

It is now clear that in Nematostella (and other cnidarians) Wnt/b-catenin signalling is a key determinant for the development of the oral domain. Wnt genes are expressed in staggered domains in the oral half of the embryo [36], a b-catenin-GFP fusion construct is preferentially stabilized in the oral territory [54][55][56], pharmacological overactivation of the pathway expands the expression of oral marker genes at the expense of aboral markers [55 ,57], inhibition of the b-catenin co-factor NvTcf has the opposite effect [55 ] and NvWnt1 and NvWnt3 synergistically can induce a secondary body axis, when ectopically expressed in the aboral domain [58]. Already at blastula stage, the oral domain is subdivided into at least four subdomains that can be distinguished by gene expression [55 ]. Interestingly, despite the importance of Wnt/bcatenin signalling for oral development, a number of the genes in the oral-most domain (termed the central domain) are upregulated upon inhibition of NvTcf and Nvb-catenin, suggesting additional factor(s) that are required for the formation of the oral pole [55 ,59]. The development of the aboral half of the embryo is also controlled by conserved patterning genes, with the transcription factor NvSix3/6 playing a key role [60 ]. However, the initial formation of the NvSix3/6-expressing aboral domain is strictly dependent on Nvb-catenin [59], showing that Nvb-catenin activity is essential for the first steps in the patterning of the entire oral-aboral axis. This is in line with the early localization of Dishevelled at the oral pole and the observation that upon bisection of 8-cell stage embryos, only the oral half is able to restore the normal pattern and form a primary polyp [61,62].

The patterning of the directive axis in Nematostella is controlled by BMP signalling [63]. This pathway is important for the patterning of the dorsal-ventral axis in bilaterians, but it is currently not clear whether these axes are homologous. Although the components of this pathway are well conserved, there are significant differences in their deployment in Nematostella. In contrast to bilaterians, NvBMP2/4 and NvBMP5-8 are co-expressed with the BMP-binding protein NvChordin. Initially, the three genes are expressed around the blastopore, but soon become restricted to one side [64,65]. Labelling of the active form of the intracellular signal transducer (pSmad1/ 5/8), however, revealed that the pathway is active on the opposite side [66 ,67 ]. This suggests that NvChordin functions to block NvBMP signalling locally and to transport it away from its source. This is different from the situation in Drosophila and vertebrates, where Chordin is expressed away from the main site of BMP expression and is involved in concentrating BMPs at the site of their production. Perhaps the more interesting difference to bilaterians is, however, the negative, instead of positive, autoregulation of BMPs. The differences in the transcriptional control are likely to be of importance to understand the evolution of BMP signalling networks in which the same players are used at different positions within the network, as is the case also for Nematostella [63].

There has been considerable progress in the work on axial patterning in Nematostella, but many key questions remain to be addressed ( Figure 1): what is the mechanism of the initial symmetry break along the directive axis? How are b-catenin signalling components localized to the animal pole of the zygote in cnidarians (in contrast to being vegetally localized in bilaterians)? What is the role of individual Wnt ligands in the patterning of the oralaboral axis and what is it actually, that becomes patterned? Interestingly, two developmental regulators of axial patterning, NvSix3/6 and NvHoxD are targeted by specific miRNAs, yet the impact of this post-transcriptional regulation is unknown (Figure 2, [42 ]).

div.head: Development of the nervous system
div.p: The nervous system of cnidarians comprises sensory cells, sensory-motor cells, interneurons (termed ganglion cells in cnidarians) and nematocytes, the highly specialized stinging cells, each consisting of several subgroups [68][69][70]. There seem to be no stereotypic positions of specific neurons in different specimens.

Besides condensations in certain parts of the body, the nervous system of anthozoans is organized mainly as a nerve net formed both in the endoderm and ectoderm [68][69][70][71][72]. Unlike in vertebrates and insects (and possibly many other bilaterians), the gradient of BMP signalling does not determine the site of neurogenesis or modulate neuronal differentiation [63,66 ,67 ]. One subpopulation of GLWamide + neurons, however, shows an early larval axial asymmetry and is affected by manipulation of Wnt and BMP signalling [73 ]. Neurons are -at least partially -generated by dedicated neural progenitor cells (NPCs) which express the transcription factor NvSoxB(2) [74 ] and whose number is negatively regulated by Notch signalling [75 ,76,77]. Basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) genes of the atonal (ath) and achaete scute (ash) families act as additional positive regulators of neurogenesis, with NvAth-like acting at the level of the NPCs and NvAshA acting mainly downstream of the other two genes in the development of a more restricted set of neurons [77,78]. These studies revealed significant similarities between anthozoan and bilaterian neurogenesis. The origin and development of NPCs in Nematostella is still poorly understood, but may serve as a paradigm for comparative studies on stem cell differentiation and the generation of cell type diversity.

The nerve net-like organization has for a long time attracted interest in the processing of information and the generation of behaviour in cnidarian nervous systems. The availability of stable transgenesis and the possibility to manipulate gene function now provides exciting opportunities to obtain new insights in these areas [20,79]. In a developmental perspective, the formation of neural connectivity via neurite guidance and synaptogenesis will likely be an important topic, in particular because of the unusual distributed origin of neurons. For analyses of neural circuits, optogenetic tools like calcium sensors for neural activity and light controlled ion channels can be expected to become important. Data acquired with these tools can be integrated with recent studies on the physiological properties of several classes of neuronal ion channels to learn about the molecular basis of conduction and transmission in cnidarian nerve nets [80][81][82][83]. Eventually, this would provide essential knowledge for understanding the evolution of centralized nervous systems in bilaterians.

div.head: Future prospects in technique and resource development
div.p: The availability of stable transgenesis and genome editing technology in Nematostella allows the adoption of the wide repertoire of tools developed in bilaterian model systems. For example, inducible and cell-type specific manipulation of gene function, targeted changes in histone modifications and ablation of specific cell populations are all in reach. The increasing number of fluorescent reporter lines will enable the generation of cell type specific transcriptome and proteome resources as a tool to test hypotheses about cell type evolution. Shortening of the generation time by modified culture conditions, the ease of genome sequencing and a growing research community interested in using Nematostella represent the opportunity to conduct mutagenesis screens, which could be an informative approach to better understand the roles of non-conserved genes. An important technology that is still missing is long-time live imaging, which will be essential for exploiting the potential of reporter transgenes. For the other promising anthozoan models, improved culture conditions and inducible year-round spawning will be the key for further development of the experimental toolkit. An important addition for understanding the diversity of anthozoan developmental biology would be the establishment of an octocorallian model system with accessible embryogenesis.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Nematostella has become a model organism not only for comparative studies, but also to address generic questions in developmental biology. In addition to the areas discussed here, the expanding resources and experimental toolkit will benefit research that takes advantage of specific aspects of the biology of Nematostella, as for example the high tolerance to varying environmental conditions and the high regenerative capacity [84][85][86][87][88]. Importantly, the advancement of anthozoan model systems for symbiosis, calcification and stress biology is imperative for attempts to counteract the global decline of coral reefs (e.g. [24,27,[89][90][91][92]).

figure.head: Figure 1 -
figure.figDesc: Genetics & Development Wnt and BMP signalling in Nematostella axial patterning. (a) b-Catenin signalling components (indicated in orange) are localized to the animal pole in cnidarians, but to the vegetal pole in bilaterians. Nematostella Wnt genes are expressed in distinct domains along the oral-aboral axis, but it is unclear whether their expression domains correspond to specific domains of the nervous system. (b) The expression NvBMPs is radialized upon BMP knockdown and suppressed upon NvChordin knockdown, revealing an unusual negative autoregulation. (c) Activation of Smad1/5/8 (shown in magenta) starts in a small domain along the directive axis of the Nematostella gastrula. (b and c) are oral views. Images in (a) from [60 ], in (b) and (c) from [67 ].

figure.head: Figure 2
figure.figDesc: Opinion in Genetics & Development miRNAs as regulators of embryonic development in Nematostella. (a) pri-miRNA-2026 is co-expressed with its target NvHoxD in the endoderm of the planula. (b) miRNA-2025 is expressed in the same aboral domain as its target NvSix3/6, however, while NvSix3/6 is expressed in the ectoderm, miRNA-2025 is expressed in the endoderm. The roles of the two miRNAs in axial patterning have not been tested. Lateral views with the aboral pole to the left are shown. Images from [42 ].

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: Work in FRs lab is funded by the Sars Centre core budget provided by the University of Bergen and the Research Council of Norway (NFR). UT receives funding from the Austrian Science Foundation (FWF, P24858, P27353 and P25993).

This study provides the first example of a neuron population that is asymetrically localized along the directive axis and shows that its development is regulated by BMP signalling. Wnt/b-catenin signalling and orally expressed sox and bHLH genes are required for the proper neurogenesis.

Richards GS, Rentzsch F: Transgenic analysis of a SoxB gene reveals neural progenitor cells in the cnidarian Nematostella vectensis. Development 2014, 141:4681-4689. A transgenic line identifies a population of mitotically active cells that give rise to the major neural cell types in Nematostella. A soxB gene is shown to be essential for neurogenesis, revealing an ancient role of the gene family in neural development.

Layden MJ, Martindale MQ: Non-canonical Notch signaling represents an ancestral mechanism to regulate neural differentiation. Evodevo 2014, 5:30. This paper shows that the achaete scute gene NvAshA acts downstream of NvNotch signalling and provides evidence that NvNotch acts via a noncanonical, SuH and hes-independent pathway.

monogr.title: use high throughput sequencing to analyse the developmental stage specific expression of Nematostella miRNAs and show that many of them are fully complementary to their target transcripts. Degradome sequencing and RLM-RACE show that slicing is a prominent mode of miRNA function

biblStruct.note: which is different from bilaterians but similar to plants

Moran et al. use high throughput sequencing to analyse the develop- mental stage specific expression of Nematostella miRNAs and show that many of them are fully complementary to their target transcripts. Degra- dome sequencing and RLM-RACE show that slicing is a prominent mode of miRNA function, which is different from bilaterians but similar to plants.

analytic.title: The authors compare transcriptome and proteome of specific stages of head regeneration in Hydra and surprisingly find only modest overlap between the two approaches, suggesting an uncoupling of transcriptional and translational regulation. They also show that early response genes of regeneration tend to be evolutionarily novel

biblStruct.note: A comprehensive transcriptomic and proteomic analysis of Hydra head regeneration. while later genes are more conserved

Petersen HO, Hoger SK, Looso M, Lengfeld T, Kuhn A, Warnken U, Nishimiya-Fujisawa C, Schnolzer M, Kruger M, Ozbek S et al.: A comprehensive transcriptomic and proteomic analysis of Hydra head regeneration. Mol Biol Evol 2015, 32:1928-1947. The authors compare transcriptome and proteome of specific stages of head regeneration in Hydra and surprisingly find only modest overlap between the two approaches, suggesting an uncoupling of transcriptional and translational regulation. They also show that early response genes of regeneration tend to be evolutionarily novel, while later genes are more conserved.
